reviews.review: This game is just amazing. Yes, the gameplay can get repetitive at times, although it's not as bad as other fps-games because of the vigors, different enemies and great scenery, but the thing that makes this game one of the best first-person-shooters ever made is the story. Elizabeth is an awesome companion that feels like a real person and not just like some free ammo and money giving pet. The story is way longer than I expected and has a few surprising twists plus an awesome ending. Just play this, it's worth the money
Que se foda joga foda da poha recomendo

This is a 8 year old game now but the graphics are just amazing, you can feel Columbia in your face when you enter this game.

If you are a fan of this saga or you just finished the other Bioshock games in the series you MUST also buy the dlc Burial at sea, it wont dissapoint i promise.

So, yeah 9/10, would play this again when i have alzheimer so i could experience the story again

Without the slightest doubt, I've never had a gaming experience better than this one. For a 2013 game the mechanics are amazing and are still quite enjoyable. The graphics are pretty good and there are lots of scenes in the game that you can spend minutes just watching them. But the strength of this game is its story. And the story, WOW, it blew my mind up. It was attractive enough that I even spend hours reading and watching other online resources to get a better grasp of the whole thing. I wish it had a story mode that you could just enjoy the whole environment and the story itself without all the shooting and looking for the loots.

And the burial at the sea episode two DLC was as perfect as the game itself. It followed a perfect stories that wrapped up the whole bioshock story, and what a masterpiece. I was thrown into the atmosphere by those amazing cutscenes.

I can't express how much I enjoyed this game. Wish there was more games like this.
The game has a lot of plot holes, but it is beautiful and deserves attention.

This game is both amazing and very repetitive in its story. The aesthetic of the game and the atmosphere of nearly every area feels polished and generally amazing, The graphics still hold up today, often you are left not even realizing how old the game really is. Some textures are really poor, but from a distance everything in this game is absolutely beautiful. The gameplay however is a different story, there less than 5 actions that you perform during the game. Following a path which you've already been down multiple times, fighting enemies in open areas, flicking levers, and watching cutscenes. While this game is really awesome the gameplay is really quite stale in most parts. The story is amazing.

Explotando por completo todos los recursos disponibles por los desarroladores en la Ã©poca, entregandonos una obra de arte que recordaremos siempre dentro del mundo de los videojuegos. 

El juego toma lugar en el aÃ±o 1912 donde Estados Unidos se encuentra en una etapa de reestructuraciÃ³n, eres Booker Dewitt un ex-detective privado que se ha endeudado a causa de las apuestas y por ello decide aceptar un trabajo. Llevar una chica sana y salva a New York.

Desde los primeros minutos del juego quedarÃ¡s FASCINADO, el aspecto visual es abundante en todo sentido. los colores pastel contrastan totalmente con el de los titulos anteriores y el diseÃ±o de personajes no busca ser realista sino ÃšNICO. Inclusive sabiendo que Infinite se desarrolla en un lugar ficticio lo que ocurre en Ã©l no estÃ¡ muy lejos de la realidad, su cultura los valores religioso e incluso el racismo y la explotaciÃ³n se ven reflejados en cada rincÃ³n (Hablando de 1912).  Â¿Y el gameplay? Bioshock Infinite no deja de ser un FPS y uno excelente, con momentos llenos de adrenalina, enemigos que te conducen a buscar alternativas y un gran sistema de combate que te obliga a utilizar todos los recursos. Just installed again to wander around in it. Still stands up graphically as a beautifully imagined alternate Earth, the satire and barbs within the story are still sharp, and the characters needed no reintroduction. De Witt and Elizabeth feel alive, while the Lucrece twins remain among my favorite in any game.

It's a first person shooter, with some light and easy to use magic to go along with that, but one which has a narrative which repays close attention.

To get the positives in order before the negatives, the gun play is at its best in this installment, shooting is very clean and doesn't feel too awkward like the previous entries, streamlined perhaps but I suppose that was the intent of the gunplay to sell it to a broad FPS audience which isn't a terrible flaw. The characters were superbly written and acted out by their VA's, Booker, Elizabeth, Comstock and the other characters largely felt like real people because of the quality of their performances. The greatest strength of Infinite however is the level design, Columbia is BLEEDING with confidence and stylized artistic flourish to show off just how majestic the city in the sky is which ultimately blinds everybody (and the player initially) to the real problems that are happening in the shadow of Comstock's own Mount Olympus.

With all these positives it's time for why this is my least favorite Bioshock in the trilogy, the upgrades and plasmids are underwhelming by comparison, shields help you remain in the thick of combat for extended periods of time but without medkits (med hypos) to keep you going it creates abrupt brakes in the combat pacing by needing those shields to recharge and fight conservatively from afar until Elizabeth throws a medkit your way, I suppose it's meant to emphasize the streamlined gunplay the strongest but by cutting out what made the IP a System Shock offspring you wind up playing a cover based shooter and then some. 

Nothing compares to the grandiose tragedy of the story however, a story that was written too big and out of proportion for its own good wrote the franchise into a corner that it has not found its way out of since Infinite's inception. Did I have a good time playing the game? Yes but only on my first play through. In retrospect the time travel and dimension hopping threw the game's modestly grounded universe from its roots which was supposed to be a spiritual successor to System Shock. Bioshock Infinite feels like an idea meant for a completely different game entirely apart that the devs elected to put down every story idea that happened to be knocking around in their noggin like a brick in a washing machine at the time and plaster it onto an immersive sim IP with a lot of weight to its name with the hope that it'll sell copies off like hot cakes rather than risk it all on an entirely different game that would have inevitably failed, and....well....if the under performing sale numbers are of any indication for its immediate future then I'm not sure if there will be any willingness to pull the IP back up from the rubble. Though there were talks of 2K bringing back the IP from the pit the series had placed itself into, both financially and story wise but it has a long climb to surmount and exceed the high precedence of expectations that will be placed on the new installment.

It's your right to enjoy and like Bioshock Infinite but this is what I felt looking back on this game, what was supposed to be a fresh jump start and take on the System Shock formula that received improvements in its 2nd installment has become buried at sea like Rapture itself all while System Shock remains alive and well, on a cliffhanger but safe in stasis like the Hacker and Soldier of old as its spiritual successors sequentially survived, died or were one note and never done again.

Honestly, this game is so depressing I'm almost tempted to say not recommended. If you suffer from mental health issues related to family or PTSD, don't buy this. If you're unable to handle unapologetic and awful turns of fate in a game, don't get it, you'll just end up whining about it. Also, as a person who absolutely hates shooters, this wasn't an easy play either, considering it's chaotic and loud on a whole other level, but then again, steampunk games usually tend to be so.

But then, how come I spent 21.6 out of the last 38-odd hours on this game, completing both the core game and DLCs? 
a) I always love clever stories, and the Easy mode minimizes the time I have to spend shooting and mauling human beings, so that worked out just fine for me. 
b) The setting of Columbia is absolute breathtaking.

I recommend skimming the history of the last two games before playing, if like me, you weren't a fan of the Rapture setting of those games and didn't finish them. It's not necessary to play them before playing the core game of Infinite, just the DLCs. 

To wrap up... was it violent? Yes. Did they play the political narrative well? Eh, it was very simplistic, and I suspect that's on purpose. What the devs did was play the theological, scientific and moral themes, questions and conundrums like a fine-tuned violin. As a student of genocide studies, I'd say the violence was a nice break from the "darker" stuff. 

Also, if you didn't like Inception, you won't like this. I guarantee. If you enjoy twisted worlds and complicated stories, go for it. It's Bioshock, emphasis on the "shock", either you already know what you're getting into, or hoooo boi, you're about to find out.
